section: The Joint Venturers shall have full and complete charge of all affairs of the Joint Venture. The Joint Venturers recognize that both of the Joint Venturers are and will continue to be engaged in the conduct of their respective businesses for their own account. Neither Joint Venturer shall be entitled to compensation for services rendered to the Joint Venture as such, but each Joint Venturer shall be reimbursed for all direct expenses, including travel, office, and all other out-of-pocket expenses incurred in the operation of the affairs of the Joint Venture and the promotion of its businesses. It is agreed that either Joint Venturer shall have authority to execute instruments of any character relating to the affairs of the Joint Venture, even those instruments that could incur liability or indebtedness for borrowed funds, dispose of assets, or purchase any items for the Joint Venture. The need for written consent or approval is only required for strategic partnerships with other organizations.
explanation: The initial sentence grants *full and complete charge of all affairs* to the Joint Venturers (plural).  The later sentence states *either* Joint Venturer has authority to execute instruments, including those that could incur significant liability. This implies unilateral power that conflicts with the initial statement of joint control. Specifically, one joint venturer could indebt the Joint Venture or dispose of assets without the other's explicit agreement, contradicting the 'full and complete charge of all affairs' requiring joint action. This undermines the concept of a joint venture requiring collaboration and mutual consent.

section: The Joint Venture shall commence on the 1st of March, 2003, and shall be effective until February 28, 2004 unless extended by either joint venturer providing notice of extension. Such extension shall be valid for one year.
explanation: This section details the term of the Joint Venture.  The core contradiction lies in the ambiguity of *either* joint venturer providing notice of extension. This suggests a single party can unilaterally extend the Joint Venture, going against the nature of a joint venture which typically requires mutual agreement to continue. This leads to the possibility of one party forcing the other into an unwanted extension, conflicting with the core principle of a joint agreement. The one year extension is a set amount which means it can be extended indefinitely by one joint venturer.

section: On any termination of the Joint Venture, its debt shall be paid or provided for in a manner deemed reasonable by a third-party mediator, regardless of the satisfaction of the Joint Venturers. Then, any unexpended portion of Joint Venture funds shall be distributed to the Joint Venturers in accordance with their prorata ownership in the Joint Venture, but all other assets of the Joint Venture shall be distributed based on the discretion of the third-party mediator, irrespective of the parties' prorata interests. If any asset is not capable of being distributed on an undivided basis, the third-party mediator shall determine the fair price and decide which party receives the asset, potentially offsetting balances to ensure fair distribution, as determined by the mediator.
explanation: There is contradictory logic in the distribution of assets upon termination. The unexpended funds are distributed proportionally, reflecting ownership, while *all other assets* are distributed at the sole discretion of a third-party mediator, irrespective of the parties' ownership interests. This is contradictory to the spirit of a joint venture, where parties typically expect a return of assets proportional to their investment or agreed-upon share. Giving the mediator full discretion to allocate assets regardless of ownership creates potential for unfair distribution and disputes, undermining the financial expectations inherent in the joint venture agreement. The term 'deemed reasonable by a third-party mediator, regardless of the satisfaction of the Joint Venturers' is contradictory. The satisfaction should be included in the decision making process.
